title: House Passes Bill Loosening Rules on PPP Small-Business Loans
summary: In separate development, Treasury and SBA set aside more funds for community lenders. WASHINGTON-The House approved a bipartisan bill that would loosen requirements on hundreds of billions of dollars in small-business loans, responding to concerns from employers struggling to stay open during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The FISA Bill Flops
summary: The surveillance court dilutes political accountability. Better to abolish it.. Nancy Pelosi is known for her iron political control over the House, but on Wednesday the Speaker suffered a rare defeat as she pulled a FISA reauthorization bill before what would have been a losing vote. This is a victory for security and political accountability, and it's worth rehearsing how we got here.

title: The Twitter Fairness Doctrine
summary: Trying to enforce online 'neutrality' is a fool's errand. Users can make up their own minds.. President Trump, personally piqued by a "fact check" that Twitter added to two of his tweets, now wants to pare back the liability protections that have helped the internet flourish for 24 years. This is a mistake, and it would drag the federal government into regulating online speech, aiming for some nebulous "neutrality."

title: A Death in Minneapolis
summary: A video of disturbing police behavior leads to violent protests.. Details about the fatal Memorial Day encounter between George Floyd and Minneapolis police remain limited. For now, all we have to go on is a highly disturbing video of Floyd on the ground, an officer's knee pressing on his neck, and pleas for air before he was brought to a hospital and pronounced dead.

title: Pelosi's Proxy Voting Ploy
summary: The House should show up to vote, as the Constitution stipulates.. Republicans probably don't want to stick around Washington, D.C., to vote on bills any more than Democrats do. But Nancy Pelosi's "proxy voting" ploy is legally dubious and will create uncertainty about any legislation Congress passes.

title: Mideast-Based NMC Health Files for Bankruptcy in the U.S.
summary: Hospital operator's chapter 15 bankruptcy filing follows fraud allegations. NMC Health PLC, a hospital operator based in the United Arab Emirates that collapsed amid allegations of a multibillion-dollar fraud, filed for bankruptcy protection in the U.S. and could liquidate as it faces shareholder lawsuits over its financial irregularities.

title: Why the Fed May Not Duck Inflation This Time
summary: Banks' excess reserves limited the money supply after 2008, but looser rules today might give way.. Is there any limit to the power Congress is willing to give to the Federal Reserve? Since 2008 lawmakers have granted the Fed the ability to pay interest on excess reserves, which allows it to buy vast quantities of government and private securities with money borrowed from the banking system. The Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 made the Fed the nation's dominant financial regulator, free of the checks and balances other agencies face from annual congressional funding, bipartisan commissions and congressional reauthorization.

title: America's Supply Chain Needs High-Skilled Migrants
summary: Trump's proposed restrictions on programs like H-1B would short-circuit attempts to bring advanced semiconductor manufacturing back.. To secure its supply chains and boost employment, the U.S. is pushing to bring home advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But President Trump is considering immigration restrictions that could sabotage those efforts-and cost American jobs.

title: Notable & Quotable: The Draft
summary: 'The draft's inequities were clear, and efforts to address them failed because the policy was inherently regressive. So too are lockdowns.'. From "Drastic Coronavirus Lockdowns Are The Most Regressive Policies Since The Draft" by J.T. Young at the Federalist, May 28:

title: The Challenge of Contact Tracing in America
summary: We're a nation of rebels, bitterly divided. Making this work will require sensitivity and tact.. Something is coming that is well-meant and seriously intended but carries the promise of trouble. It is the planned state-by-state coronavirus contact-tracing regime. It has all the potential to be an onerous system that provokes resentment, spurs anxiety, and invites pushback.

title: The Covid Political Earthquake
summary: Subsidies will soon end. Americans will then feel the economic pain-and revolt.. The political press is preoccupied with the electoral implications of the virus crisis, and pundits insist the 2020 election will be about the Trump daily soap opera. But an emerging cultural and economic time bomb is about to explode. There has never been a wider gap between average Americans' perception of their own economic situation and the reality of it. America could soon have its most combustible political environment in recent history.

title: The Coronavirus Isn't God's Will
summary: The Lord calls us to join with him to fight suffering and to choose life over death.. Facing death concentrates the mind religiously. Google searches for "prayer" spiked in March as Covid-19 spread, and again in April as the extent of the loss became clear. Feeling helpless, many people turn to a higher power. Others wrestle with how God could allow innocents to suffer. Some religious leaders speak of accepting that suffering is inexplicable and death inescapable. All we can do, they say, is respond with care and love for our fellows.

title: Costco's Sales Cool as Coronavirus Stockpiling Slows
summary: Company's quarterly gains lagged behind big discounters and dollar stores; Nordstrom hit by closures. The coronavirus stockpiling that cleaned out some Costco shelves in March has cooled.

title: Notable & Quotable: An Idea for Oren Cass
summary: 'With so many people being paid goo-gobs of money to perform activities that you have perceptively identified as valueless, you can make yourself incredibly rich. . .'. From "Another Open Letter to Oren Cass" by Don Boudreaux, at CafeHayek.com, May 20:

title: 'Bouton' Review: Maverick on the Mound
summary: Jim Bouton pitched-and then he dished. His riotous memoir 'Ball Four,' now 50 years old, is a timeless account of life in the big leagues.. The best thing about baseball happens also to be the worst thing about baseball-its adherents' almost pathological aversion to change. This year, however, Major League Baseball officials have been forced to contemplate the previously unthinkable to salvage what remains of the season. Prospective innovations run from expanding the playoff pool to 14 teams (from 10) to redrawing divisions regionally and banning spitting. Look out for more Yankees-Mets games and universal designated hitters. And good luck chewing tobacco.

title: Barr Names Prosecutor to Investigate Unmasking
summary: Trump says revealing Flynn's identity to Obama officials was attempt to undermine him. Attorney General William Barr has tapped a federal prosecutor to examine Obama administration officials' use of the practice known as "unmasking" around the time of the 2016 presidential election, which President Trump has portrayed as an effort to undermine him.

title: Most Countries Fail to Capture Extent of Covid-19 Deaths
summary: Many leave the untested off coronavirus tallies; Belgium doesn't, despite the outcry. A growing pool of global death statistics indicates that few countries are accurately capturing fatalities from the new coronavirus-and in some the shortfall is significant.

title: Salesforce Trims Full-Year Outlook in Response to Coronavirus
summary: Business-software provider says it extended financial relief to some pandemic-affected customers. Salesforce.com Inc. cut its full-year earnings outlook as the company said it provided payment relief to some customers and made new investments in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pending Home Sales Plunge, but Housing Market Shows Signs of Recovery
summary: Real-estate brokers, economists and some home buyers are looking beyond the pandemic-driven slump in home sales and seizing on signs that the housing market is strengthening. Real-estate brokers, economists and some home buyers are looking beyond the pandemic-driven slump in home sales and seizing on signs that the housing market is strengthening.

title: As U.S. Ramps Up Reopening, Restrictions Return in South Korea
summary: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo says order would allow businesses to deny entry to anyone not wearing mask; few countries may be accurately capturing coronavirus-death data. • Cities and states moved ahead with plans to restart their economies as the U.S. surpassed more than 100,000 deaths from the new coronavirus four months after its first reported appearance in the country.

title: Novartis Inks Deal to Make Experimental Coronavirus Vaccine
summary: Swiss drugmaker will make gene-based Covid-19 vaccine being developed at Massachusetts Eye and Ear, Massachusetts General Hospital and University of Pennsylvania. Novartis AG has agreed to manufacture a gene-based coronavirus vaccine being developed by scientists at Massachusetts Eye and Ear hospital, Massachusetts General and the University of Pennsylvania, paving the way for human testing to begin later this year.

title: New York City Seeks Power to Borrow Up to $7 Billion
summary: State lawmakers mull legislation as Cuomo grants businesses right to refuse service to customers without masks. The New York state Legislature on Thursday declined to vote on a measure that would have authorized New York City to borrow billions of dollars as the city struggles to contain the costs from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Amazon to Keep Most of the Jobs It Added During Pandemic
summary: E-commerce giant says 125,000 temporary positions will be converted to permanent. Amazon . com Inc. will keep most of the U.S. jobs it added to meet demand in March and April as it sees the surge in online orders during the pandemic as a harbinger of lasting demand for its products and services.

title: IASB Provides Relief to Companies Accounting for Leases
summary: Rule change applies to coronavirus-related rent concessions that reduce lease payments. The International Accounting Standards Board on Thursday granted temporary relief to companies accounting for rent concessions they received on leases due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Wielding Sanctions, U.S. Disrupts Iranian Fuel Shipments to Venezuela
summary: Sanctions threat stems some deals with Caracas while avoiding armed confrontation, U.S. officials say. Washington has disrupted planned Iranian fuel deliveries to Venezuela by threatening sanctions against shippers, U.S. officials said Wednesday, temporarily thwarting a burgeoning economic alliance between two of America's biggest rivals.

title: 24 Hour Fitness Searches for Bankruptcy Loan
summary: Company is in talks with landlords and plans to close some gyms permanently in bankruptcy. Midprice gym chain 24 Hour Fitness Worldwide Inc. is seeking a financing package to stay afloat through a possible bankruptcy filing that could come within weeks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'Space Force': Out of This World Office
summary: Steve Carell stars as a general tasked with putting boots on the moon in the new Netflix comedy.. Among the enchanting aspects of "Space Force" (Friday, Netflix), and they're countless, is its capacity to seem what it decidedly is not. It's very soon clear that this wit-drenched series (created by Steve Carell and Greg Daniels, showrunner of "The Office") isn't meant as a sendup of the current resident of the White House. Still, there's no missing the hints of reference to Donald Trump or someone very much like him that inevitably rise up, periodically, in the course of this 10-part extravaganza. Every demand attributed to the POTUS of this series, every worry expressed by a fearful presidential staff about the need to satisfy his wishes, every reference to POTUS tweeting, unavoidably summons thoughts of the actual POTUS.

title: 'Viral: Antisemitism in Four Mutations' Review: An Endemic Disease
summary: A PBS documentary looks at the long-documented hatred of Jews through a quartet of contemporary examples.. In "Viral: Antisemitism in Four Mutations" (PBS On Demand, through June 26), George Will provides a succinct description of the uses of anti-Semitism: "In healthy societies with problems, people ask, 'What did we do to cause this?' In unhealthy societies with problems, they say, 'Who did this to us?' And the Jews are always a candidate.''

title: Projecting the Big Screen's Future
summary: Our film critic and top cinematographers weigh in on moviemaking in the age of streaming.. In a lifetime of watching movies, I have always tried to see the big picture-not the significance of it all, necessarily, but the big picture up there on a theater screen rather than the little picture on a home TV. Like a moth to a projector, I've been drawn to huger-than-life images that take me out of myself by banishing everything else from my blissed-out sensorium.

title: Brown University to Cut 11 Varsity Sports
summary: Squash, fencing and others are downgraded to club sports; rosters of surviving teams will grow. Brown University said it would cut its roster of varsity sports to 29 from 38, in an effort to spend more on its remaining teams and make them more competitive while keeping its budget flat.

title: Tweet Responsibly: A Guide to Twitter in 2020
summary: Between increased discussion of pandemics and politics, Twitter has turned into a messy place. Here are the tools and policies to know about upon entering.. The first rule of Twitter ? Don't use Twitter. It's a hellhole.

title: 'To Master the Art' Review: Comfort Food for the Soul
summary: The biographical play about Julia Child is a story of discovering destiny and a portrait of a loving marriage.. As the pandemic continues to wreak financial havoc on America's performing-arts organizations, more theater companies (though not nearly enough) are turning to webcasts of various kinds as a desperately needed source of revenue. Some, like New York's Irish Repertory Theatre, are presenting new online-only productions, while others are streaming older shows drawn from their archives. TimeLine Theatre, a much-admired Chicago troupe that specializes in "stories inspired by history," has chosen the latter course with "To Master the Art," a bioplay about Julia Child that was commissioned by the company in 2008, had its premiere in 2010, and was revived there in 2013. Staged and co-written by William Brown, one of Chicago's leading directors, and starring Karen Janes Woditsch, a Chicago-based actor of the first rank, it's a play nicely suited to the moment, an intelligent entertainment about the comforting delights of cooking and eating. Taped at the beginning of the show's 2013 run, it also serves as a treasurable reminder of the famously high quality of Chicago theater in general and TimeLine Theatre in particular.

title: U.S.-China Fears Take Air Out of Stock Rally
summary: Dow drops in final hour as Trump says he will hold a press conference regarding China and Hong Kong. A rally in U.S. stocks came to an abrupt halt Thursday after President Trump said he would hold a press conference on China, raising jitters about a fresh standoff between the world's two largest economies.

title: Easing Unemployment Claims Show Slower Pace of Virus-Related Layoffs
summary: U.S. workers seeking assistance remain historically high, but number receiving benefits fell for the first time since February. The number of workers receiving unemployment benefits fell for the first time since February and new weekly claims continued to ease, offering evidence that layoffs related to the coronavirus pandemic are slowing.

title: Senior House Lawmakers Push to Speed Up Broadband Funding
summary: Bipartisan bill is a bid to close gaps in high-speed internet service exposed by the coronavirus pandemic. WASHINGTON-Two House lawmakers are pushing the Federal Communications Commission to speed up broadband infrastructure funding to rural parts of the U.S., in a bid to close gaps in high-speed internet service exposed by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Iran's Economy Is in Crisis; Its Stock Market Is on a Tear
summary: Tehran Stock Exchange's main index has shot-up nearly 100% since mid-February. Crushed by U.S. sanctions and weak oil prices, Iran has one of the world's most battered economies. It also hosts one of the best-performing stock markets.

title: The NFL Is Testing Another Officiating Solution. Will It Work?
summary: The league is experimenting with increased communication between the booth official and referees in the preseason after momentum has built for a sky judge. Tens of millions of people could plainly see when Los Angeles Rams defensive back Nickell Robey-Coleman committed a blatant pass interference during the NFC Championship in 2019, with ramifications that would decide whether the Rams or the New Orleans Saints would advance to the Super Bowl. The problem was that the few people who didn't see it were the only ones who could do something about it: the referees.

title: Higher Death Rates Found Among Cancer Patients With Covid-19
summary: Study finds 13% of patients who had cancer that was either active or in remission died within 30 days of their coronavirus diagnoses. Cancer patients infected with the new coronavirus are dying at significantly higher rates than Covid-19 patients in the general population, a new study suggests.

title: U.S. Consumed More Renewables Than Coal for First Time in 134 Years
summary: Shift reflects growth of renewable energy, continued decline of U.S. coal power. The U.S. consumed more renewable energy than coal last year for the first time since 1885, according to the Energy Information Administration.

title: U.S. Charges North Korea Officials With Illegal Money Transfers
summary: Indictment says representatives operated front companies at secret branches abroad and made prohibited payments in U.S. dollars. U.S. authorities unsealed a sweeping indictment charging more than 30 people with helping North Korea illegally transfer $2.5 billion since 2013, amid dim hopes for resumption of long-stalled nuclear talks between the two countries.

title: UPS Adds Peak Surcharge as E-Commerce Soars
summary: Package giant to impose extra fees on Amazon, Best Buy, others responsible for surge in shipments including oversize items that are testing delivery networks. United Parcel Service Inc. is adding "peak" surcharges for companies that have been inundating its delivery network with many more packages and oversize items during the coronavirus pandemic, an unprecedented move to manage a summer flood of shipments and higher costs.

title: Rescheduled Boston Marathon Has Been Canceled
summary: Boston Mayor says September event 'would not be responsible or realistic'. The 2020 Boston Marathon, which had been pushed from April 20 to September due to the coronavirus pandemic, was canceled Thursday. It's the first cancellation in the history of the race, which this year would have been run for the 124th time.

title: University of California Drops SAT and ACT
summary: Until the early 1900s, most schools had their own entrance exams.. Regarding your editorial "California's College Testing Mistake" (May 23): Until the early 1900s, most schools had their own entrance exams. Harvard hopefuls would have to go to Cambridge to sit for a test. How would a lower-income student be able to apply to multiple schools?

title: Immigration Issues Dim Grad Student Plans
summary: I hope America's leaders recognize the high costs to the U.S. economy should we continue to bring forth proclamations and rhetoric that encourage the world's skilled workers to go elsewhere. "Managing Your Career: Consultancies Delay New Hires' Start Dates" (Business & Technology, May 18) highlights the impact Covid-19 is having on job offers to recent business-school grads, citing visa issues as one determining factor. Concerns over visa availability combined with harsh immigration rhetoric have long been on the minds of international students considering the U.S. as a study destination. They are primary factors for many prospective students ultimately choosing Europe or Canada for study over the U.S. Recent data collected by the Graduate Management Admission Council states that nearly one-third of prospective international students preferring to pursue graduate business education in the U.S. cite "social reaction to international students" as an area of concern, which is even higher than the ability to complete visa requirements (29%). This is a troubling statistic for American businesses that compete with the rest of the world for the best and brightest workers and innovators. By contrast, Canada is permitting students to complete up to 50% of their studies remotely (including outside Canada) without affecting their postgraduate work eligibility.

title: Baby Powder Should Join Bleeding as an Obsolete Tool
summary: Ending the use of talc-based baby powder is right, but long overdue.. James R. Copland bemoans Johnson & Johnson 's marketing decision to stop selling talc-based baby powder in the U.S. and Canada ("Johnson & Johnson Takes a Powder," op-ed, May 23). The author is a lawyer, not a pediatrician, and seems unaware that, asbestos-contamination issues aside, using talcum powder on babies is a remnant of advice from another time. That information is readily available to any doctor, new parent or lawyer. As New York's Casey Stengel reminded sportswriters, "You could look it up!"

title: Global Glut Keeps a Lid on Natural-Gas Prices
summary: Mild May weather has limited domestic demand, brimming storage facilities abroad have reduced exports and the flow from oil wells hasn't declined by as much as expected. Even the biggest producer in the country is backing away from the dismal market for natural gas.

title: Justice Department Blocks Marijuana Workers From Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Even in states that declare medical-marijuana businesses essential, federal government says bankruptcy is off the table for cannabis workers. The Justice Department is preventing struggling cannabis businesses and their workers from accessing bankruptcy to weather the coronavirus-related downturn, even in states that determine medical marijuana is an essential industry during the pandemic.

title: House Cancels Vote to Renew Surveillance Powers
summary: Some Democratic progressives also express a lack of support, citing inadequate privacy amendments. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives scrapped a planned vote Thursday on major national security legislation to renew a set of expired domestic surveillance powers after support for the bill eroded following a veto threat by President Trump.

title: China Loosens Business Travel From Korea and Germany, Pressuring Other Countries
summary: Companies are trying to rebuild supply chains, boost sales and increase productivity, moving quickly to gain a competitive edge. As businesses world-wide struggle to resume operations following months of coronavirus-imposed economic lockdown, two planeloads of German executives traveling to China in coming days are upping pressure on foreign rivals to resume international business travel.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended May 23
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: It's a Tough Time to Be a Fan of Bats
summary: Resume Subscription. Winifred Frick, the chief scientist at a bat conservation society, was picking up her son from a theater troupe in Santa Cruz, Calif., just before lockdown when a helper there asked: Why have bats done this to us?

title: Best Hammocks to Let You Sway Away From Crowds
summary: Sales of the solo loungers are spiking as quarantined Americans seek to catch a few rays and social distance. Here's how to find a nylon nest that fits you right.. IF YOU'VE VISITED a park lately, you've likely spotted a hammock dangling between trees, its inhabitant lost in a book, napping or daydreaming about a virus-free future. Sales of solo loungers have soared as folks look for ways to relax in open air, a reasonable distance away from the madding crowds. "After a two-week dip when the lockdown started, sales have been extremely strong," said James Hennessy, COO of Hennessy Hammock.

title: English Premier League Plans to Return on June 17
summary: The 20 clubs voted to approve a plan, known as Project Restart, that would see the final 92 games of the season played behind closed doors. The most popular sports league on Earth, the English Premier League, is planning a return to action on June 17 after a three-month pandemic hiatus.

title: NYC Uses Ankle Bracelets Instead of Jail Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: New program uses electronic monitoring for pretrial defendants. New York City officials have begun using electronic monitoring to speed the release of defendants from jails during the coronavirus pandemic, the first time the technology has been used for people awaiting trial there.

title: UAW Staffer Sues Union Alleging Sexual Harassment, Retaliation
summary: Lawsuit marks the second time this year the UAW faces sexual-harassment allegations involving top officials. A woman on staff at the United Auto Workers has filed a lawsuit claiming she was sexually harassed by higher-ranking UAW officials and that the union failed to take corrective action when she complained of the alleged incidents.

title: Investors Get More Bang for Their Buck at This Dollar Store
summary: Coronavirus stockpiling wasn't enough to pull Dollar Tree's sales growth up to Dollar General's, but it was enough to pick up its downtrodden share prices.. Despite their misleadingly similar names, Dollar Tree 's shareholders have earned chump change compared with those of Dollar General over the years. Last quarter's strong sales somewhat leveled that share-price performance-perhaps overly so.

title: A Jewish Dynasty in a Changing China
summary: For more than a century, the fortunes of the powerful Kadoorie family have been a barometer of Chinese openness to the world.. Since 1880, when an Iraqi Jewish refugee named Elly Kadoorie arrived in Hong Kong, China has gone through a series of revolutions-from domination by Western powers to independence, from Nationalist to Communist rule, from colonialism to capitalism to communism. Through it all, the Kadoorie family have been a barometer of the country's openness to the world, rising to become the richest Western family in China. Leaders have been seeking their advice for generations, drawn by their combination of business skills and political acumen. Now, as China cracks down on dissent in Hong Kong and defiant protesters again take to the streets, the problem facing the family-like other companies and governments seeking to deal with a more repressive and nationalistic regime-is whether China will continue to welcome them.

title: EU Took Big Step With Coronavirus-Recovery Proposal-Now Comes the Hard Part
summary: Plan would push group closer to federal structure, rather than looser political and trading bloc it is now. BRUSSELS-Plans announced by European Union officials Wednesday to address the bloc's coronavirus-triggered economic crisis have surprised longtime EU watchers with their speed and gutsiness. If member states get onboard, the program stands to chart a new path for the bloc.

title: White House Won't Issue Economic Projections This Summer
summary: Projections wouldn't provide a 'meaningful snapshot' of economy because of uncertainty caused by pandemic. WASHINGTON-The White House won't issue updated economic projections this summer because of uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic, according to a senior administration official.

title: Williams Doesn't See Fed's Support of Economy Causing Inflation Surge
summary: New York Fed chief says, 'I don't really see a lot of these actions as ones that will overheat the economy'. Federal Reserve Bank of New York leader John Williams said he sees little risk of an inflation surge despite a wave of central bank support for the economy and financial system prompted by the coronavirus crisis.

title: A False Dilemma Fuels the Lockdown Wars
summary: Both sides are dug in on extreme positions, but the facts say it's time to reopen, carefully.. As often happens in politics, those debating how to reopen the economy have dug in on extreme positions and ignored the data. The two prevailing positions are that we should either open the economy immediately and return to life as normal, or keep the economy in total lockdown until a vaccine arrives. Both are equally ridiculous, and the truth is somewhere in between. Finding the middle ground requires examining the data and incorporating lessons learned. Anyone who looks at the facts is likely to come to one conclusion: It's time to reopen, carefully and with exceptions.

title: Amid a Pandemic, China Picks a Border Fight With India
summary: A war may be unlikely, but by throwing its weight around, Beijing is making enemies needlessly.. Are China and India about to start a war in the Himalayas? If historical precedent holds, the continuing standoff involving thousands of troops in multiple places along the contested 2,200-mile boundary likely won't escalate to armed combat. But one thing is clear: Ties between the world's two most populous nations are fraying rapidly.

title: New York City Mayor's Race Feels the Impact of the Coronavirus
summary: While election is more than a year away, the lockdown has hurt candidates' ability to raise money and campaign. Dianne Morales quit her job working at an antipoverty organization in the South Bronx in January to spend the spring campaigning and raising money for her bid to be New York City's next mayor.

title: Coronavirus Will Change the World. Good Luck Figuring Out How.
summary: Our columnist contemplates five areas of uncertainty that leave the world on the edge of major changes. Boardrooms and newspaper columns are full of speculation about how different the world will look once Covid-19 is finally defeated. Investors are placing bets based on long-term winners and losers.

title: Going Up: A Malibu Mansion With Its Own Funicular Lists for $125 Million
summary: Late country singer Kenny Rogers was hit with a $2 million fine for installing the lift when he owned the home in the 1980s. A cliff-top Malibu, Calif., mansion with a funicular leading down to the ocean is coming on the market for $125 million.

title: A Funicular of One's Own
summary: The Malibu property also has a beach cabana, recording studio and dance studio.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: WHO Faces Pressure to Reform-With Expanded Powers
summary: Australia's prime minister has backed giving the agency similar powers to weapons inspectors, but change wouldn't be easy. Days after President Trump said the U.S. would freeze funding for the World Health Organization last month, Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison pushed for a revamp of the agency's mandate to give it powers to investigate potential pandemics similar to weapons inspectors.

title: The Worst Wine Advice Ever-and How to Avoid It
summary: Whether it's an imperious sommelier or a salesperson promising inside intel, bad advice comes from many corners. Our wine columnist considers some egregious examples-and the value of maintaining a healthy skepticism..

title: A Truck Driver's Long Haul During Coronavirus Crisis: 'You Realize Just How Alone We Are'
summary: Robert Greene has recently hauled everything from meat to bodies bound for the crematorium. Robert Greene's lonely job has gotten even more isolating in recent months. The longtime truck driver's income has plummeted, and places to eat, shower and sleep during his journeys have become harder to find. His wife's recent battle with coronavirus only increased the stress felt by someone spending so much time on the road.

title: U.S. Economy Contracted 5% in the First Quarter as Coronavirus Hit
summary: GDP recorded largest quarterly rate of decline since last recession. WASHINGTON-The U.S. economy's first-quarter contraction was slightly steeper than initially estimated, and a key measure of corporate profits weakened as the coronavirus and related shutdowns began to have an effect.

title: Behind the Fall of China's Luckin Coffee: a Network of Fake Buyers and a Fictitious Employee
summary: Resume Subscription. China's upstart Luckin Coffee Inc. grew at a blinding pace. It opened stores faster than Starbucks Corp. , doubled its valuation to $12 billion eight months after going public and pleased its big-name investors in the U.S.

title: The Solace of Solitary Encounters With Classical Music
summary: Nothing can replace a live concert, but listening to great music alone can be the opposite of isolation and an antidote for loneliness. Nothing can replace the experience of a live concert of classical music. Yet magnificent as such events are, distractions often come along with the experience: the towering person in front of you blocking your view, the crinkle of someone unwrapping a candy, the dreaded cough at precisely the wrong moment. This dreadful pandemic has given us an opportunity to explore a different kind of listening-something both intimate and global, akin to meditation, in which you can sit inside yourself for whatever amount of time you choose or can spare.

title: The Best Spy Novels, According to Espionage Experts
summary: Novelists Daniel Silva, Jennie Fields and International Spy Museum's Chris Costa on the covert-op plots they've found most riveting-and realistic. "'The Quiet American' is not a classic tale of espionage, but Graham Greene's masterpiece of love, betrayal and murder set against the backdrop of the French collapse of Indochina is my favorite novel of foreign intrigue. John le Carré's Karla trilogy featuring the matchless George Smiley is undoubtedly the finest series of novels of pure espionage ever written. That said, I've always had a soft spot for le Carré's 'The Russia House' and its Scotch-addled hero Barley Blair, who wisely chooses the girl over his country."

title: Test Indicates Sen. Tim Kaine Had Coronavirus
summary: The Virginia Democrat and wife recently tested positive for coronavirus antibodies. Sen. Tim Kaine (D., Va.) said he and his wife have recently tested positive for antibodies to the novel coronavirus, making him the second senator thought to have had the Covid-19 illness.

title: Custom Art Is Helping High-End Homeowners Paint a Clearer Picture
summary: Resume Subscription. When Jason Saft, a real-estate agent at Compass and founder of Staged to Sell Home, was called in to style a $2.495 million apartment at 44 Gramercy Park North in Manhattan that was about to be listed, one of his first moves was to take inventory of the artwork and fill in the blanks.

title: China Votes to Override Hong Kong's Autonomy on National Security
summary: Resolution paves way for new legal and enforcement steps in Hong Kong to help China quash anti-Beijing protests, and sets up conflict with U.S.. China's legislature approved a resolution to impose national-security laws on Hong Kong, overriding the territory's partial autonomy in a bid to crush anti-Beijing protests that have challenged Chinese leader Xi Jinping.

title: Turkey Borrowed Foreign Currency as Lira Tumbled
summary: Central bank short-term borrowing from its local banking system jumped to a record in April. Turkey's central bank ramped up foreign-currency borrowing from local banks to a record high last month, as it moved to reverse a steep fall in the local currency.

title: Coronavirus Outbreaks Threaten Oil Majors' Biggest Projects
summary: Recent spate of infections show oil and gas work sites remain vulnerable to the virus. Oil companies including Chevron Corp. , Exxon Mobil Corp. , Royal Dutch Shell PLC and Total SA are scrambling to cope with coronavirus outbreaks among their workers that could threaten the profitability of some of their largest projects.

title: As States Reopen, the Boss Wants to Know What You're Up To This Weekend
summary: Employers worry that workers' off-duty activities could risk infection in the workplace. Companies have a new question for employees: Any plans this weekend?

title: The Hidden Meanings of Noise
summary: Scientific breakthroughs often depend on discovering the meaning of seemingly random fluctuations.. In his essay "On Noise," the 19th-century German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer wrote that "the most eminent intellects have always been strongly averse to any kind of disturbance, interruption and distraction, and above everything to that violent interruption which is caused by noise." He was referring to audible sounds, in particular the "infernal cracking of whips...which paralyzes the brain."

title: From Graffiti and Boarded Up Windows, a Rare Streamline Moderne Home Emerges in Miami Beach
summary: A pair of Detroit snowbirds paid $1 million for the architecturally distinct property and spent another $1 million to restore its authentic style. When Detroit snowbirds Kyle Evans and Michael Chetcuti first saw the 1936 Streamline Moderne home in Miami Beach, they had to stretch their imaginations to envision how it must have looked when first built. The home in front of them had boarded up windows and graffiti scrawled on its classic white exterior. Remarkably, it also had an asking price of more than $1 million.

title: Meet New York's Social-Distancing Ambassadors
summary: City uses a small army of employees to encourage residents to keep six-feet apart and wear masks in public, as summer season kicks off. Zakiyah Degraffe normally oversees a community facility for New York City's Department of Parks & Recreation. But during the coronavirus pandemic, she has taken on a different job with the parks team that requires diplomacy delivered with a smile, even if it is behind a mask.

title: Coronavirus Is Buying Time on Climate Change. Will We Make Use of It?
summary: Carbon emissions appear to be plateauing, making dire scenarios less likely; but limiting warming will still require steep emissions cuts. Back in 2014 the United Nations-affiliated panel on climate change predicted carbon-dioxide emissions from fossil fuels would keep rising steadily, hitting 40 billion metric tons this year and, in some scenarios, nearly doubling again by 2050.

title: Nissan Loses $6.2 Billion as It Prepares to Slim Down
summary: Auto maker to reduce capacity by 20%, close plant in Barcelona. TOKYO- Nissan Motor Co. said it would slash production capacity and trim its model lineup after reporting a $6.2 billion loss in its latest fiscal year, one of the worst in its history.

title: Jonathan Karp Named CEO of Simon & Schuster
summary: Publishing veteran to lead unit that ViacomCBS put on the sale block. Jonathan Karp has been named president and chief executive officer of book publisher Simon & Schuster, succeeding Carolyn Reidy, who died of a heart attack earlier this month.

title: GE Finally Has Its Lightbulb Moment
summary: The business that started it all has been sold a bit late and for a modest price. How many General Electric chairmen does it take to change a lightbulb?

title: News Corp to Stop Printing 100 Australian Newspapers
summary: Company says 76 local and regional newspapers in Australia would become online-only titles. SYDNEY- News Corp said it would stop printing more than 100 Australian newspapers by the end of June, closing 36 outright and moving the rest solely to the Internet, in its latest response to media shifts accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Restaurants Say Socially Distant Dining Could Wipe Out Business
summary: Owners pare staff, calculate how long they can last as officials restrict seating to contain coronavirus. Restaurants that built their businesses on keeping seats full are trying to figure out how to run at a fraction of that capacity.

title: Barton Myers is Selling His Award-Winning Santa Barbara Home for $8.2 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. "My original plan was that we would spend the rest of our lives here," says architect Barton Myers, 85, standing in front of his longtime home, a striking glass-and-steel compound on the outskirts of Montecito, Calif. It is a quintessentially crisp and clear Santa Barbara afternoon, and the views stretch down over the hills and straight out to sea. Oil rigs dot the Pacific Ocean, stationed like guardsmen in front of the Channel Islands, birds chirp incessantly and a lone paraglider sails overhead. "But things are different now."

title: An Architect's Award-Winning California Compound
summary: Barton Myers designed his property as a series of four single-level steel pavilions on three stepped terraces.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Draft Order Could Seek to Limit Protections for Social-Media Companies
summary: Executive order comes after Twitter fact-checked president's tweets. WASHINGTON-A draft of an executive order President Trump is expected to sign on Thursday would seek to limit the broad legal protection that federal law currently provides social-media and other online platforms, according to people familiar with the draft.

title: Harvard Professor Alberto Alesina Helped Revitalize Political Economy
summary: Italian-born economist argued public-spending cuts could boost economies and suggested lower taxes for women.

title: Covid-19 Antibody Tests Pose More Questions Than Answers
summary: Health histories, recent results open the possibility the new coronavirus was circulating in the U.S. before January. Armed with positive antibody tests for Covid-19 and a history of related symptoms, some Americans think they had the disease as early as fall 2019.

title: Nissan and Renault Plan Post-Merger Integration Without a Merger
summary: The Franco-Japanese car-making alliance is embarking on a radical path towards much closer collaboration. Can companies cut their way out of a crisis? And has this crisis become so bad that radical cultural change is possible? In the case of Nissan Motor Co. and its global car-making alliance with Renault SA and Mitsubishi Motors Corp., it is easier to be optimistic about the first question than the second.

title: James Bond's Miami Beach Hotel Is Shaken, Not Stirred, by Debt
summary: Luxury destination is among properties seeking to renegotiate terms with lenders, highlighting toll of coronavirus pandemic. The Fontainebleau is a jewel of Miami Beach, a modernist resort that was the venue for Frank Sinatra's TV special with Elvis and a backdrop for the James Bond movie "Goldfinger." To investors, the property is feeling less glamorous.

title: Chef Dominique Crenn Is a Star. But She's Also a Fighter.
summary: From a French orphanage to her third Michelin star-the only woman in the U.S. to have three-Crenn talks past, present and future while sheltered with her fiancée, actress Maria Bello. On a Thursday afternoon in mid-March, Atelier Crenn, the three-Michelin-starred restaurant near San Francisco's Marina District, was bustling with chefs preparing their stations for dinner, waiters fussing with flowers and linens, and deliveries arriving through an alleyway entry. Chef-owner Dominique Crenn was pacing among the velvet armchairs and marble-topped tables next door at Bar Crenn, the retro wine bar attached to her fine-dining flagship via a courtyard. Her iPhone lit up with email, text messages and headline notifications about the rippling worldwide effects of the novel coronavirus. "Atelier is going to be OK," she said. "We had 10 cancellations in the last two weeks-that's not bad.

title: How Camila Cabello Became Friends With Her Anxiety
summary: "There was something hurting inside me, and I didn't have the skill to heal it or handle it. In order to heal it, I had to talk about it.". In her own words, 23-year-old Grammy-nominated singer/songwriter Camila Cabello talks about dealing with her internal struggles for Mental Health Month.

title: Facebook's Zuckerberg Defends Policy on Political Speech
summary: 'I don't think Facebook or internet platforms in general should be arbiters of truth,' CEO says. Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg backed his stance of largely not interfering with politicians' posts on the company's platform as President Trump is expected to sign an executive order that would make it easier for regulators to hold social-media companies liable for curbing users' speech.

title: Minor Leaguers Make $400 a Week. The A's Are Cutting Off Payments.
summary: The team plans to stop compensating its minor-league players at the end of the month, likely leaving them without a baseball paycheck until next April. During the coronavirus pandemic's shutdown of Major League Baseball, the Oakland Athletics, like every other team, have continued paying their minor leaguers a weekly $400 stipend, even though there probably won't be any minor-league games this year.

title: Chinese Policy Makers Have Stimulus Measures Ready, Premier Says
summary: Li Keqiang said China's abandonment of its formal growth target didn't diminish the importance of economic growth. BEIJING-China's premier said Thursday that policy makers have more stimulus measures ready in case of a further deterioration in the economy, which he said would keep the world's second largest economy "on a steady course" as Beijing wrestles with the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic and rising geopolitical tensions.

title: As Lockdowns Are Lifted, Slow Return to Normality Begins
summary: Economies are returning to life, but at different paces around the world and with varying degrees of damage to their economies and societies. After the big freeze, the slow thaw.

title: Office-Supply Company Makes a Pivot-to Your Home Office
summary: W.B. Mason didn't do home deliveries of office basics until the pandemic forced its hand. CEO Leo Meehan: 'We found something we like'. Office supplier W.B. Mason isn't much like those corporate giants that have flourished in the pandemic. Its trucks, emblazoned with the company's mustachioed mascot, mostly serve downtown office districts in the U.S. Northeast, where the virus has hit the hardest. And the Brockton, Mass., company's $2 billion in annual sales provide a far thinner capital cushion than the sums companies like Amazon.com Inc. and Walmart Inc. have handy.

title: Quiet That Noisy Quarantine Home...With Decorating Advice?
summary: If your cooped-up family is raising a racket, these five interior-design hacks can elegantly muffle it. AFTER THREE-ODD MONTHS of commuting only as far as the kitchen, you've likely come a long way in transforming your living space into a workplace. Perhaps you've converted a closet into an excessively cozy home office, duct-taped blankets over windows to quash unflattering backlight and stationed fresh flowers in view of your webcam to assure your colleagues and yourself that you're flourishing.

title: China's Cash Cow-How Hong Kong Bankrolls the Mainland
summary: Here's what's at stake for China in the U.S. declaration that Hong Kong's autonomy has been curtailed. A U.S. decision that Hong Kong's autonomy has been curtailed raises questions about how Washington will treat the city in the future, and about its standing as a global financial hub. Here's what's at stake for China.

title: HP Misses the Work-From-Home Hookup
summary: Despite rush to beef up home offices, HP's revenue from laptops and desktops suffered its largest drop in four years last quarter. Workers snapping up personal computers to wait out the coronavirus pandemic at home isn't proving to be the windfall many expected.

title: Q&A: How Lawmakers Cast Proxy Votes During Coronavirus
summary: The historic change to allow remote legislating in the House moves ahead despite facing a legal challenge from Republicans. The House of Representatives is allowing lawmakers to cast votes by proxy this week for the first time, enabling members to vote remotely during the coronavirus pandemic. Here is how proxy voting works, and the logistical and legal challenges it faces.

title: America's Churches Weigh Coronavirus Danger Against the Need to Worship
summary: State rules and personal feelings among the faithful vary widely, while experts say houses of worship are prime spots for the spread of the virus. MURRIETA, Calif.-Churches weren't legally allowed to be open in California this past weekend, but at 412 Murrieta, a nondenominational church in this town southeast of Los Angeles, parishioners sat side-by-side on chairs less than a foot apart with no masks.

title: No Pool? Stock Tanks Are the Cool New Alternative
summary: With public pools closed, small steel tanks meant for cattle have become the Instagram-friendly way to take a dip. How to add one to your backyard.. SINCE THE TIMING of public pool openings remains murky, Austin interior designer Terah Kelley plans to outmaneuver the abusive summer sun by plunging into a galvanized steel tub in her backyard, one more properly intended to hydrate livestock. Recently, she and her husband have even built a bar and cabana-outfitted with a refrigerator, fan and teak benches-alongside their 6-foot-wide "stock tank pool." No cattle have complained. "Since we're not going on vacation anytime soon, we're making vacation come to us," said Ms. Kelley.

title: Fashion Stockrooms Are Bursting at the Seams
summary: Unsold merchandise has piled up at clothing retailers during lockdowns. That is bad news for profit margins but great for shoppers.. With fashion retailers sitting on a glut of unsold clothing, shoppers can expect serious bargains once shops reopen. The hit to profit margins could be dire.

title: Ill-Timed Health-Care Buyouts Bruise KKR and Blackstone
summary: Coronavirus adds to woes at Envision and TeamHealth, as some patients stay away from hospitals. Two big health-care buyouts are shaping up to be among the worst-performing private-equity investments in recent years. The coronavirus pandemic is only the latest reason why.

title: Weakening of Foreign Currencies Opens Up Hedging Options
summary: Weak currencies and market fluctuations prompt some CFOs to re-evaluate currency exposure. Alamos Gold Inc. last month decided to take advantage of low currency-exchange rates for the Canadian dollar and Mexican peso against the U.S. dollar. The Canadian gold miner protected more of its currency exposure and extended that cover for a longer period.

title: Mexico's Leader Has Answer for All His Needs: The Army
summary: Resume Subscription. MEXICO CITY-On a recent day, Army Col. José Cruz Vargas Rangel rode atop a Humvee as thousands of workers and hundreds of dump trucks zipped back and forth just outside the Mexican capital, laying the foundations of a new $3.2 billion airport.

title: How the U.S. Could Really Hurt China
summary: Scrapping the privileges the U.S. affords Hong Kong would downgrade the city's economic role, but a broader basket of financial sanctions could be even more painful for China. The U.S. determination that Hong Kong is no longer autonomous from mainland China has significant implications for the city's exporters and businesses. But that could pale in comparison to further action by the U.S. to use its dominant position in the global banking system against Beijing.

title: Twitter's Labels for Trump Tweets Show Tech Platforms' Split Over Political Speech
summary: Facebook said claim that prompted Twitter action complied with its rules. Twitter Inc.'s move to label two tweets by President Trump as misinformation highlights a widening divide among big tech platforms on how they handle political speech, an increasingly contentious issue as the U.S. presidential election approaches.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: House Delays Vote on Bill to Renew Surveillance Powers
summary: President Trump had threatened to veto it, and resistance had emerged from some progressives in the Democratic Party as well. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives postponed a vote late Wednesday on major national security legislation to renew a set of expired domestic surveillance powers after passage appeared uncertain because of a veto threat by President Trump.

title: Two Chinese Tech Firms Prepare Hong Kong Listings
summary: Listings plans by JD.com and NetEase to be reviewed Thursday by Hong Kong's stock exchange as they prepare to follow Alibaba. Two of China's most valuable U.S.-listed companies are pushing ahead with multibillion-dollar share sales in Hong Kong, amid growing pressure from U.S. lawmakers for greater financial scrutiny of Chinese companies.

title: American Airlines to Cut 30% of Management and Administrative Staff
summary: Carrier is among those seeing demand pick up, but modest gains won't be enough to save thousands of jobs. American Airlines Group Inc. will cut its management and administrative staff by 30% as the airline prepares to shrink, with demand decimated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Boeing Details Plans for Mass Job Cuts
summary: Aerospace company starts forced layoffs as it reduces jetliner production. Boeing Co. intends to shed more than 13,000 employees, the plane maker said Wednesday, including the first round of compulsory cuts as part of previously announced plans triggered by the coronavirus-driven collapse in global air travel.

title: George Floyd's Death in Custody Draws Condemnation From Law Enforcement Officials
summary: Resume Subscription. MINNEAPOLIS-Crowds clashed with police for a second night to protest the death of George Floyd after a police officer held him down with a knee on his neck, a technique not approved by the city's police department and one that drew rare widespread condemnation from police across the country.

title: Apple Lands Martin Scorsese Movie Starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert DeNiro
summary: 'Killers of the Flower Moon' to be labeled an Apple Original Film. Apple Inc. has nabbed director Martin Scorsese's next film, "Killers of the Flower Moon," starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert De Niro, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Brazil's Daily Coronavirus Death Toll Surpasses That of U.S.
summary: Latin American country reports that 1,039 people died from Covid-19 in one day as president calls for the economy to reopen. SÃO PAULO-Brazil has reached a grim milestone, reporting more Covid-19 deaths in one day than the U.S., which until recently had logged the most daily fatalities from the disease.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Top 100,000 as South American Cases Surge
summary: Milestone comes as models vary on ultimate estimated toll; Disney details some reopening plans. More than 100,000 people in the U.S. have died from the new coronavirus, as reopenings across the country accelerated and rising infections in Brazil, Peru and Chile placed the Americas firmly at the center of the pandemic.

title: 'I Feel Like a Failure': Dayton Reopens and Surveys Coronavirus Lockdown's Toll
summary: As an Ohio city re-emerges from its shutdown, it discovers wounds left by the scramble to hold the virus at bay. DAYTON, Ohio-Each morning, Nan Whaley walks her dog, takes an online yoga class and then, in her role as mayor of this city of 140,000, girds herself for a steady stream of calls from constituents asking for help navigating life during the pandemic.
